title: OsCommerce Verisign Plugin
description: The plugin utilized Verisign (now owned by PayPal)'s payflow link system. A system that required the user to leave a customers website to go to one owned by Verisign and fill out their credit card information. A process that was less than optimal, and would on frequent occasion result in orders not being completed, as it was unclear to the user how to finalize the transaction. Using the plug-in I developed, it emulated the process of Verisign's more expensive premium service named Payflow Pro to the customer.
contributions: Integrated the equivelence of the premium Verisign Payflow service, using the free Payflow Link API. This resulted in a much better customer experience for free, and increased conversion rates.
reason: Eventually the need was replaced byPayPal, and better online Credit Card Processing services like Stripe.

title: Nobis Command Center
description: Order processing and fulfillment application which allowed for 1 tap order fulfillment for existing customers. Issuing a bill of materials, and printing out all necessary postage, to be handed off to shipping department to fulfill orders. Integrated into OsCommerce for realtime notifications of purchasing.
contributions: Designed and implemented an end-to-end order management system that streamlined business operations.
reason: We shut down Nobis Technologies in 2009, no longer needed.

title: Eō
description: A virtual telepresence and sightseeing videogame that rewarded players for virtually visiting and exploring geographic points of interest using a treadmill or stationary bike as the controller. The project aimed to combat obesity and inactivity by making exercise social, fun, educational, and a view-port to the outside world.
contributions: Led development of this innovative fitness game concept that combined 3D scanning technology with exercise equipment to create immersive virtual travel experiences.
reason: Kickstarter campaign was unsuccessful and the technology required for high-quality 3D scanning of cities was prohibitively expensive at the time.
